text: In CCDM 30.4.3.1.4, the organization name for the Division Counsel (Large and Mid-Size Business) was changed to the Division Counsel (Large Business and International).
Obsolete e-learning information in CCDM 30.4.3.1.2 was removed. In CCDM 30.4.3.1.6 the for D.O. 92 was updated.

Communication
) This section establishes policy and procedures for training within the Office Chief Counsel. (

) A high quality, well trained workforce is critical to successful our mission. Counsel’s goal is to provide training that is meaningful, timely, challenging, and provides all employees with the skills they need to perform their job to their maximum potential. (

) Managers at all levels are responsible for supporting the training program ensuring that their employees receive the training they need. Managers are assessed on their responsibility to identify and provide training for their dinates. Training responsibilities are included in goals and are evaluated in management portion of the LD-
, CC/IRS Performance Appraisal Form. (

) Training in its broadest sense includes any education conducted in a variety formats, i.e., classroom, video, technology-based, teleconference, web streaming, that clearly relates to and enhances an employee’s skills, knowledge, and ability to perform their job. (

) The Human Resources Division, under the direction of the Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management), is responsible for ensuring that the training policy of the organization is adequately promoted and supported. responsibilities of the Division include: a. Conducting an ongoing assessment of Counsel training needs, providing support and guidance to the National Training Advisory Board (see CCDM

) b. Managing all nationally-sponsored training programs c. Providing advice to managers on employee development d. Using team development techniques to assist work groups to improve formance, relationships, or attempt to resolve conflicts (

) The primary purpose of the core curricula is to better target our training by dressing the key skills and knowledge needed by our attorneys, and the developmental activities, skills and knowledge that are needed by managers and executives. The curriculum is designed so that each attorney, manager and executive progresses sequentially through three levels of learning. (
) The three basic areas of the legal curriculum are: (cid:
) Fundamental skills sets (cid:
) Core skills (cid:
) Specialized skills (

) These areas focus on basic attorney skills, expertise and knowledge for working in a specific functional area, or specialized skills which relate to particular area or issue in tax law. For instance, the fundamental skills sets area contains programs in advocacy and oral presentation, courtroom skills, legal and brief writing, and negotiation skills. The core skills area focuses on program areas such as tax litigation, general litigation, criminal tax, and general legal services. The third area, specialized skills, focuses on narrow areas, such as bankruptcy, employee plans, and international. (
) The basic attorney training programs currently provided to newly hired field and National Office attorneys serve a vital role in developing the attorneys’ Chief Counsel Directives Manual

) These areas focus on basic attorney skills, expertise and knowledge for working in a specific functional area, or specialized skills which relate to particular area or issue in tax law. For instance, the fundamental skills sets area contains programs in advocacy and oral presentation, courtroom skills, legal and brief writing, and negotiation skills. The core skills area focuses on program areas such as tax litigation, general litigation, criminal tax, and general legal services. The third area, specialized skills, focuses on narrow areas, such as bankruptcy, employee plans, and international. (

) To ensure that these early training needs are met, and to ensure that is relevant, effective and efficiently administered, attorneys should be trained the basic functional area(s) where they will spend a very substantial part of their time. This training should be scheduled within the first

months of ployment to the extent that courses are available. When an experienced attorney is assigned work in another function and needs the basic training in that area, he/she may be nominated to attend that program. (
) The basic areas in the Management Curriculum are: (cid:
) Fundamental supervisory skills (cid:
) Developmental managerial skills (cid:
) Executive skills (
) These areas focus on basic management and supervisory skills, continuing management education, and executive and leadership development. (

) The programs included in the fundamental supervisory skills are primarily an introduction to management and leadership. Overall, new managers are exposed to such topics as evaluating employees, counseling employees, personnel issues. (

) The developmental managerial skills area focuses on providing training in areas such as communications, coaching, change, and leadership. These courses are designed to provide managers with on-going training to their skills. (

) The executive and leadership skills area primarily addresses strategic planning, executive coaching skills, systems thinking, and creating one organization. Although many of these seminars and programs are concerned with broad organizational issues, they are also intended to provide leadership development. (

) Basic administrative/technical skills for all support staff and office (cid:
) Supervisory skills for office managers and administrative officers (

) File organization (cid:
) Guidebooks (cid:

) Office managers and administrative officers receive additional training on supervisory and management skills on topics such as evaluating and ing employees as well as team building and personnel issues. (
) Training is conducted through a variety of formats including traditional classroom, video, technology-based and on-the-job training. (
) The Office of Chief Counsel provides a variety of training opportunities. All these opportunities are intended to enhance the skills, knowledge, and of an employee in the current job. (

) Chief Counsel Sponsored-training is offered through the Training and nications Branch. These programs are targeted for various groups of employees, including attorneys, paralegals, and managers and executives. Chief Counsel sponsored programs are announced at the beginning of fiscal year through the Training and Communication Web site at least six to eight weeks prior to the beginning of a program. The method of delivery for Chief Counsel courses range from the traditional classroom, Interactive Telecast (IVT), web streaming or CD/ROM. (

) IRS Sponsored-training is offered separately by the IRS. These programs offered on an ad hoc basis throughout the year. Specific information the various programs can be obtained on the IRS Web site. The IRS also contracts for e-learning classes. (

) Continuing Professional Education (CPE) consisting of educational and stantive tax law courses are presented in the National Office and selected programs offered via satellite broadcast to all locations. The programs are available to Counsel attorneys, IRS employees, State and other Federal Agencies. A variety of courses are taught each year. Some of these ized courses are also sometimes offered for LL.M. (Taxation) credit in a cooperative venture with various universities. Information regarding the program can be obtained through the Training and Communications (

) Nationwide Continuing Legal Education (CLE) symposiums are managed coordinated by the Training and Communications Branch. Staff members with designated business unit employees to determine locations, develop agenda, course materials, visual aids, etc. The Training Branch also the process of obtaining CLE pre-accreditation and paying any applicable for these nationally sponsored programs. Each attorney is still responsible seeking and maintaining individual bar memberships by filing appropriate cations with the State bars. (

) Out-service-training is provided by outside vendors or contractors, e.g., American Bar Association, National Institute of Trial Advocacy. Topics range from substantive tax law to various procedural issues. Interest in these programs is identified through each Division Counsel office and/or Chief Counsel Area. (
) On-the-Job-Training is provided through each individual office. This includes shadow assignments, developmental assignments, and other forms of obtained through on-the-job activities.
Personnel Administration, Training, Equal Employment Opportunity (

) Appropriate and periodic training is an essential and integral part of develop- ment and maintenance of a capable and qualified workforce. It is, therefore, Needs imperative that the Office of Chief Counsel timely and accurately assess training needs to maintain short-term and long-term staffing and planning goals. (

) The identification of training needs should first start with the identification of knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSA) required for maximum effectiveness in and Process positions. Once KSAs are identified, a manager should assess what KSAs required to reach maximum effectiveness. When identifying ways to acquire needed KSAs, it is important to examine both training and non-training ap- proaches. (

) The Training and Communications Branch, in conjunction with the National Training Advisory Board, annually conducts an assessment of training This assessment, in the form of a survey, is sent directly to all Division Counsel and Associate Chief Counsels in the July/August time frame. The survey is intended to assess the needs for training in various areas for the upcoming fiscal year. All course proposals are based on historical precedent well as recommendations from various program managers and functional sponsors. (

) Once the survey is completed, it is then analyzed and presented to both the National Training Advisory Board and the Associate Chief Counsel (Finance Management). A training plan is then proposed based on identified needs budget projections. A final training plan is developed during the later part of September each year. (

) All Chief Counsel Training Programs are evaluated by the students, and program manager. The purpose of the evaluation is to ensure that the of Training subject matter was effectively delivered, both substantively and in terms of good presentation techniques. (

) The first level of evaluation is conducted at the conclusion of the program through a Level I evaluation, and is designed to assess the content of the course as well as the individual performance of the instructors. (

) In addition, a Level II evaluation is conducted three months after the conclu- sion of a program. The primary purpose of the Level II evaluation is to both the student’s and manager’s perspectives on how much of what was taught is actually being used on the job. (

) The Office of Chief Counsel has a long history of using tests in training classes. Hundreds of National Office attorneys have been tested upon tion of CPE courses. With the expanded availability of these courses Counsel’s Distance Learning Program on the IRS Satellite Network, several hundred field attorneys have also taken tests at the conclusion of CPE courses. The testing policy outlined below expands the current Counsel CPE testing policy to other Counsel courses. (

) When appropriate, all courses more than three days in length will contain a test. The decision about the feasibility of testing will be made jointly by the course developers, the functional sponsors, and the training staff. In some Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
V

(02-17-2006) Evaluation of Training Programs

cases, there may be both a pre- and post-course test. This will better achievement in the course, given the differing levels of knowledge and ence students bring to a given course. Programs in which testing would be appropriate include: a. Basic attorney training programs such as Trial Advocacy Skills Training, General Litigation Attorney Training, and Basic Criminal Tax Training b. Substantive intermediate training programs such as Bankruptcy Seminar c. Skills training programs such as Instructor Training Programs in which testing would not be appropriate include: a. Sessions such as Advanced Bankruptcy Practice Roundtable, Criminal Symposium and International CPE b. Classes lasting fewer than three days The term “test” can refer to a variety of methods of evaluating the success the course and the performance of the students. This may include, but is limited to, written examination, application of case studies, presentation of written papers, or performance-based exercises such as role plays, mock trials, or practice presentations. Course instructors are responsible for assessing student performance on test. Student performance should be assessed against the objectives of the course, i.e., did the student successfully demonstrate achievement of the course objectives? Training staff members are responsible for assisting course developers with the development of testing components; they are also responsible for instructors with the methodology for assessing student performance. Results of any test will be used in the following ways: a. Each student will receive performance results on a pass, fail or superior scale. In general, the rating of superior should reflect outstanding mance and should be limited to no more than

% of the total number students in a class. b. The testing results for all students will be compiled, without identifying formation, and will be used by the instructors to assess overall accomplishment of objectives and by the training office to assess the overall effectiveness of the course. c. Results of student performance on a test will be one aspect of performance that, along with others, may be taken into account in assessing employees. Course announcements will indicate whether or not a test is required. All training programs sponsored by the Training and Communications are advertised on the Training Web page of the Chief Counsel Intranet site during the first quarter of the fiscal year. The Web site outlines all the programs that are identified as having the highest priority through the needs assessment, and provides a description and target date for each program. Courses are displayed in a variety of formats including a calendar format lists training opportunities for each month. Chief Counsel Directives Manual

All training programs sponsored by the Training and Communications Branch are advertised on the Training Web page of the Chief Counsel Intranet site during the first quarter of the fiscal year. The Web site outlines all the programs that are identified as having the highest priority through the needs assessment, and provides a description and target date for each program. Courses are displayed in a variety of formats including a calendar format that lists training opportunities for each month.
Personnel Administration, Training, Equal Employment Opportunity (

) Individual programs are announced on the Web site six to eight weeks prior the program and an e-mail notification of the announcement is sent to all employees. The course announcement contains a general description of program, the target audience, dates, and location of the training. (

) Registration for all training programs is done on-line through the Training site. Manager’s approval is required. The employee and manager receive firmation via e-mail of their registration (request to take the training). The registrants’ names are provided to the training contacts and final selections attendance are made by the business unit. (

) Employees not selected for the training are notified by the business unit. Selected employees are notified by the Training Office through written reporting instructions. The reporting instructions contain administrative tion regarding the program, an agenda, and participant roster. (
) Any specific concerns regarding a program, as well as any changes in the ticipant roster should be directed to the program manager. (

) The National Training Advisory Board (NTAB) is an executive group which meets one or two times per year to: a. Ensure that training efforts move the organization towards its mission its goals b. Review the results of the annual needs assessment survey to make ommendations on the relative priority of Counsel training classes, both terms of balancing priorities among functions and among categories of employees within the organizations c. Consider and make recommendations on many of the difficult issues countered in the training arena, such as how to select the best faculty, successful accomplishment of employee development goals, and the fectiveness of testing d. Provide periodic assessment of the overall effectiveness of Counsel’s training program (
) The NTAB serves in an advisory capacity to the Deputy Chief Counsels for Operations and Technical. It is chaired by the Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management). (
) Permanent members of the Board include the Chairman and from: (cid:
) Division Counsel (Small Business/Self-Employed) (cid:
) Division Counsel (Large Business and International) (cid:
) Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration) (cid:
) Associate Chief Counsel (International) (who also represents and Special Industries, Income Tax and Accounting, Corporate, and Financial Institutions and Products) (cid:
) Associate Chief Counsel position that is rotated annually among Tax, General Legal Services and Tax Exempt and Government Entities

(03-01-2011) The National Training Advisory Board
Communication

) The development of employees to their maximum potential is one of the responsibilities of a manager. This includes providing the means for to develop the skills necessary to perform their job and provide an for employees to advance within the organization. The manager is for identifying training needs of employees and providing direction and guidance for new employees. The manager should initiate training programs the office, include employees in training provided by the Training and nications Branch, as well as appropriate IRS Training Programs. (

) Key responsibilities of managers include: a. Determining the developmental needs of new and experienced b. Determining availability and types of training to meet the needs of the vidual employee c. Monitoring and evaluating the results of training programs that have attended. This includes the completion of a Level II evaluation for Chief Counsel sponsored programs. (
) The process of determining the developmental needs of employees (cid:
) Making a list of essential knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs) for each type of position in the office of (cid:
) Identifying individual training needs of each employee on the basis of formance evaluations and interviews (cid:
) Planning specific training to meet the needs of each employee (

) It is important for managers to differentiate between the needs of new employees and experienced employees. The new employee and the experi- enced employee have different training needs and require different levels of supervisory controls. (

) With the new employee, the focus should be on orienting the employee to Office of Chief Counsel, including the mission of the Office, the relationship with Treasury, IRS, Department of Justice, and the U.S. Tax Court, the zational structure of the Office (including who’s who), and office procedures. addition to new employee orientation sessions, it is important to provide opportunity for success for new employees and to develop the skills the employee’s KSAs. These training opportunities can include the following: (cid:
) Developmental assignments (cid:
) Appointing a senior employee as a mentor to the new employee (cid:
) Attending conferences and/or court appearances with employees (cid:
) Providing input on their performance (

) For the experienced employee, the training emphasis should be on advanced and specialized skills as well as career advancement. It is also important that experienced employees be encouraged to develop indepen- dence and autonomy. In addition to the advanced training programs offered the Training and Communications Branch, opportunities for researching and presenting in-house seminars on topics of special interest to the office and acting assignments should be considered as enhancement opportunities.

) There are a variety of training opportunities available to employees of the Office of Chief Counsel. This information is outlined under CCDM the Types of Training. and Types of (

) It is the manager’s responsibility to ensure that not only do employees training in order to effectively perform their job assignment, but also that the proper employees attend particular training programs. CASE (Counsel Automated Systems Environment), reviewing employee caseloads, and new work assignments can all be used to determine which employee(s) to send training. CASE is particularly useful in determining how much time an employee is spending on the subject matter of available training programs. (

) It is important for the manager to discuss expectations before the employee attends a training program. This would include any new job assignments or and Evaluate responsibilities that the employee would receive after the training. of Training (

) The manager should meet with the employee after training to discuss the perience and raise any questions or concerns regarding the training. At this time the manager should provide any evaluative information and reinforce remaining expectations. (
) This subsection specifies the general requirements for requesting training conducted by an organization other than the IRS, and applies to all Training of the Office of Chief Counsel. (
) Employees must receive prior written approval to attend any type of conducted training, conference, or tax institute at Government expense. approval is obtained by submitting a separate SF
, Request, Agreement, and Certification of Training for each individual for whom desired. (

) Out-Service training should not be requested when a Chief Counsel or IRS course (self-study or otherwise) can reasonably provide the training required. (

) Employee attendance at non-IRS training/conferences requires official approval. No enrollment arrangements may be made prior to such approval. Advance payments made by employees before proper approval are made at the employee’s own risk. (

) In the event an employee who has been approved for out-Service training becomes unavailable for such training, he/she must IMMEDIATELY notify the approving official of such fact so that a timely substitution can be made or course vendor can be requested to cancel the nomination, whichever is priate. ) Out-Service training should only be approved if comparable training is not available through courses offered by the Chief Counsel’s Office or through to which employees may be sent. (
) Out-Service training must be related to the current duties of the employee. (

) Out-Service training should not be approved for the sole purpose of a degree (i.e., the training should also be work-related) and, where academic degree training is obtained, must otherwise comply with

must be accompanied by a narrative justification for at the course, the brochure announcing the course (or a duplicate of the brochure for each attendee) and a completed enrollment form for each attending (these forms are normally found in the brochure announcing the program). Originating offices should retain a copy of this material. (
) Upon the receipt of a request for Out-Service training in the Division Counsel or Associate Chief Counsel Office, the SF

should be reviewed for com- pleteness and accuracy. The exact method for tracking receipt, approval, and processing of the form will be left to the discretion of each Division Counsel Associate Chief Counsel. After approval by the Division Counsel or Associate Chief Counsel, the form must be approved by the designated Training The Training Officer can be the Division Counsel or Associate Chief Counsel their designee. This authority cannot be re-delegated below the Area or Deputy Associate Chief Counsel. After approval by the authorizing official, the request must be entered into the Requisition Tracking System (RTS).

In the event an employee who has been approved for out-Service training later becomes unavailable for such training, he/she must IMMEDIATELY notify the approving official of such fact so that a timely substitution can be made or the course vendor can be requested to cancel the nomination, whichever is appro-

Upon the receipt of a request for Out-Service training in the Division Counsel or Associate Chief Counsel Office, the SF 182 should be reviewed for com- pleteness and accuracy. The exact method for tracking receipt, approval, and processing of the form will be left to the discretion of each Division Counsel or Associate Chief Counsel. After approval by the Division Counsel or Associate Chief Counsel, the form must be approved by the designated Training Officer. The Training Officer can be the Division Counsel or Associate Chief Counsel their designee. This authority cannot be re-delegated below the Area Counsel or Deputy Associate Chief Counsel. After approval by the authorizing official, the request must be entered into the Requisition Tracking System (RTS).
Personnel Administration, Training, Equal Employment Opportunity (

) Each Division Counsel or Associate Chief Counsel is responsible for ensuring that the approval process is completed before any employee attends Out- Service training. If the approval process has not been completed, the employee’s attendance at the training represents an unauthorized action for which the individual employee will be liable. (

) Employees are cautioned that the mere forwarding of the requisite training paperwork by mail or by interoffice messenger service to the approving office does not assure that such documentation has in fact been received or processed. Employees should not report to a training course on the assump- tion that their request has been approved until notified of such fact, nor they assume that they have in fact been enrolled in the course unless the cedures specified in the subparagraph, below, have been met. (

) While employees should not make plans to attend training courses until they have been officially notified of the approval, such notification does NOT indicate that they have been enrolled in the course by the course sponsor. In the process of approving a training request, the course sponsor is not ap- proached until the designated officials have approved the request and the request have been entered and approved in the Requisition Tracking System (RTS). At that point, the necessary paperwork is forwarded to the course sponsor or registration is faxed or phoned in to enroll the nominee. If a nominee has not heard from the course sponsor within two days of the he/she should contact the approving official so that steps can be taken to the enrollment. It is particularly important to follow this procedure where town travel is involved. (
) This provision is intended to advise Counsel employees of the requirements the Office of Government Ethics regulations at
CFR. §

(g), and the related Office of Chief Counsel policies and procedures pertaining to an em- ployee’s acceptance of free attendance at seminars, conferences, receptions, dinners, or similar events, when attendance would benefit the Service. Inquiries concerning this provision should be addressed to Chief, Ethics and General Government Law Branch, Office of Associate Chief Counsel (General Legal Services). (

) The general rule in the Standards of Ethical Conduct for Employees of the Executive Branch is that an employee may not accept a gift from a prohibited source or that is given because of the employee’s position. However, the Standards contain exceptions permitting an employee to accept some gifts. employee may accept an unsolicited gift having a market value of $
or less per source per occasion, provided that the aggregate market value of gifts received from any one person shall not exceed $

in a calendar year. When an employee is assigned to participate as a speaker or panel participant or otherwise present information on behalf of the agency at a conference or event, the acceptance of an offer of free attendance at the event on the day the presentation is permissible when provided by the sponsor of the event. (

) Additionally, when there has been a determination that an employee’s atten- dance is in the interest of the agency because it will further agency programs and operations, an employee may accept a sponsor’s unsolicited gift of free attendance at all or appropriate parts of a widely attended gathering of mutual interest to a number of parties. 30.4 Personnel Administration, Training, and Equal Employment Opportunity

) Each Division Counsel or Associate Chief Counsel is responsible for ensuring that the approval process is completed before any employee attends Out- Service training. If the approval process has not been completed, the employee’s attendance at the training represents an unauthorized action for which the individual employee will be liable. (

) Employees are cautioned that the mere forwarding of the requisite training paperwork by mail or by interoffice messenger service to the approving office does not assure that such documentation has in fact been received or processed. Employees should not report to a training course on the assump- tion that their request has been approved until notified of such fact, nor they assume that they have in fact been enrolled in the course unless the cedures specified in the subparagraph, below, have been met. (

) While employees should not make plans to attend training courses until they have been officially notified of the approval, such notification does NOT indicate that they have been enrolled in the course by the course sponsor. In the process of approving a training request, the course sponsor is not ap- proached until the designated officials have approved the request and the request have been entered and approved in the Requisition Tracking System (RTS). At that point, the necessary paperwork is forwarded to the course sponsor or registration is faxed or phoned in to enroll the nominee. If a nominee has not heard from the course sponsor within two days of the he/she should contact the approving official so that steps can be taken to the enrollment. It is particularly important to follow this procedure where town travel is involved.
town travel is involved. (
) This provision is intended to advise Counsel employees of the requirements of the Office of Government Ethics regulations at
CFR. §

(g), and the related Office of Chief Counsel policies and procedures pertaining to an em- ployee’s acceptance of free attendance at seminars, conferences, receptions, dinners, or similar events, when attendance would benefit the Service. Inquiries concerning this provision should be addressed to Chief, Ethics and General Government Law Branch, Office of Associate Chief Counsel (General Legal Services). (

) The general rule in the Standards of Ethical Conduct for Employees of the Executive Branch is that an employee may not accept a gift from a prohibited source or that is given because of the employee’s position. However, the Standards contain exceptions permitting an employee to accept some gifts. An employee may accept an unsolicited gift having a market value of $
or less per source per occasion, provided that the aggregate market value of gifts received from any one person shall not exceed $

in a calendar year. When an employee is assigned to participate as a speaker or panel participant or otherwise present information on behalf of the agency at a conference or other event, the acceptance of an offer of free attendance at the event on the day of the presentation is permissible when provided by the sponsor of the event. (

) Additionally, when there has been a determination that an employee’s atten- dance is in the interest of the agency because it will further agency programs and operations, an employee may accept a sponsor’s unsolicited gift of free attendance at all or appropriate parts of a widely attended gathering of mutual interest to a number of parties.
30.4.3.2 (02-17-2006) Widely Attended Gatherings
page (

) A gathering is widely attended if it is expected that a large number of persons will attend and that persons with a diversity of views and interests will be present, for example, if the event is open to members from throughout the in- terested industry or if those in attendance will represent a range of persons interested in a given matter. The decision as to whether an employee’s atten- dance at a widely attended gathering would be in the agency’s interest is required to be made by an employee’s supervisor or other appropriate official in the employee’s chain of management. (

) Where an invitation to attend a widely attended gathering is extended by an organization the majority of whose members have interests that may be affected by the performance or nonperformance of the employee’s duties, a written determination must be made by the employee’s supervisor or other propriate official in the employee’s chain of command, that the agency’s interest in the employee’s attendance outweighs any potential that could result in an appearance of favoritism or undue influence on his official activities. (
) Factors that should be considered include: (cid:
) The importance of the event to the agency (cid:
) The purpose of the event (cid:
) The nature and sensitivity of any pending matter affecting the interest of person who has extended the invitation (cid:
) The significance of the employee’s role in any such matter (cid:
) The identity of other expected participants (cid:
) The market value of the gift of free attendance (

) The possibility of conflicts of interest must be considered when the approving authority ratifies the acceptance of free attendance. Examples of conflicts of interest include employees accepting free attendance from an nization with a pending question before the Service regarding its tax-exempt status or employees being involved in any question or controversy with such an organization. (

) When there has been a determination that an employee’s attendance is in the interest of the agency because it will further agency programs and operations, an employee may accept, from a person other than the sponsor of the event, an unsolicited gift of free attendance at all or appropriate parts of a widely attended gathering of mutual interest to a number of parties if more than
persons are expected to attend the event and the gift of free attendance has market value of $
or less. (

) Free attendance includes waiver of all or part of a conference or other fee, provision of food, refreshments, entertainment, instruction, and materials provided to all attendees as an integral part of the event. (

) Free attendance does not include travel expenses, lodging, entertainment col- lateral to the event, or meals taken other than in a group setting with all other attendees. However, the Government Employees Training Act,
U.S.C. §

, allows employees to accept contributions and payment of travel, subsis- tence, and other expenses incident to attendance at non-Government training or meetings if such contributions or payments are offered by a tax exempt or- ganization under IRC

) Employees may not accept reimbursement for travel expenses from an zation that has open issues facing litigation. (
) Records must be maintained by the approving authority on any travel expenses accepted under the authority of
U.S.C. §
The records will include:
The name of the recipient (and spouse if applicable) who has traveled
The amount and method of payment
The name of the organization providing the payment
The nature of the meeting or similar function
The time and place of travel, the nature of the expenses
Copies of the travel authorizations
A copy of the required written authorization for the acceptance of the expenses (

) These records should be maintained as official records for a period of six years. Upon completion of the travel, a report of the acceptance of travel expenses, containing the above information and copies of documents, will forwarded to the IRS’ Office of Travel Management and Relocation.
